awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Expanded Correlative Dynamics and Meteor Studies Using the Southern Argentina Agile MEteor Radar
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Gravity waves are common disturbances in the earth?s atmosphere and they are an important contributor to energy and momentum transport through the atmosphere. The southern tip of South America is known as a "hotspot" of gravity wave occurrence. In this region, gravity waves are caused by prevailing winds from the Southern Ocean encountering the Andes mountain range. From there, they propagate upwards into the upper atmosphere (>80 km altitude), and into the space environment above 120 km (75 miles).  Gravity waves are, essentially, packages of energy and momentum and so their ability to transport this energy and momentum up into the upper atmosphere has very important implications for the dynamics of that region; implications that we have yet to understand fully.

The specific objective of the study was to determine the amount of gravity wave energy and momentum that was reaching the upper atmosphere from lower levels over the southern region of South America.  

The project used observations of mesospheric nightglow made during 2017-2018 by the Boston University optical all-sky imager. The imager is located at Rio Grande, Argentina (53.6S, 67.8W). The naturally-occurring nightglow acts as a passive tracer of the dynamics occurring within the 80-100 km altitude region of the Earth's atmosphere, known as the upper mesosphere.

The observations were also made in collaboration with a number of other instruments located near the site including a meteor wind radar system, an IR wide-field imager, and a Rayleigh lidar.

The observations were analyzed to yield the amount of gravity wave occurrence at the site and the amount of energy and momentum flux associated with the waves during the project.

The study found a strong seasonal variation in mesospheric gravity occurrence with increased activity occurring during the winter months. The increase during the winter months was attributed to a combination of changes in prevailing tropospheric and stratospheric winds that provided for favorable propagation environment for the upward propagating waves.

More importantly, the study found that the gravity waves exhibited values of momentum flux that were 10 to 100 times larger than observed at other global locations. The result illustrates the large discrepancy that exists in the current understanding and modelling of the dynamics of the earth upper atmosphere on regional and global scales. Further study is required to understand quantitatively the significance and contribution of gravity waves to the upper mesosphere in the context of global circulation and modelling.
